column1: intrainingdoc 160706371708 "2017-05-15 20:40:16 GMT" http://intrainingdoc.tumblr.com/post/160706371708/anotherdayforchaosfay-mamalizmas "anotherdayforchaosfay:  mamalizmas:  dreamlightasafeather:  IF YOU NEED TO CALL 911 BUT ARE SCARED TO BECAUSE OF SOMEONE IN THE ROOM
column2: dial and ask for a pepperoni pizza. They will ask if you know youâ€™re calling 911. Say yes
column3: and continue pretending youâ€™re making an order. Theyâ€™ll ask if thereâ€™s someone in the room. You can ask how long it will take for the pizza to get to you
column4: and they will tell you how far away a dispatcher is. Here is an example video  Reblog to literally save a life  Iâ€™ve done this.Â  Iâ€™m alive because of this.Â   My flat-mateâ€™s date for the night was almost as drunk as her.Â  She had passed out in her room and locked the door.Â  He refused to leave because he wanted to have sex.Â  He also demanded food because he was dealing withÂ â€œwhiskey dickâ€.Â  He didnâ€™t like the lack of food in the fridge.Â  I called 911
column5: did the stuff stated above
column6: and he was getting PISSED about how long theÂ â€œorderâ€ was taking.Â  He took my phone
column7: demanded theyÂ â€œhurry the fuck upâ€.Â  Police arrived two minutes later
column9: and helped me file a police report.Â  Pressing charges wasnâ€™t necessary because he had warrants on him from THREE different states for the very thing he planned to do to me.Â  Several months after this happened one of the officers informed me he was charged with two felonies because he crossed stay lines
column10: and will be serving no less than 35 years in prison.Â  The officer ripped into my flat-mate about her bringing home complete strangers
column12: knowing full well this shit could happen.Â   This was 14 years ago.Â Â  Do the pizza order
column13: do it as calmly as you can.Â  The dispatcher I spoke to said things like this: â€œIf heâ€™s drunk say you want mushrooms.â€Â  I said I want extra mushrooms. â€œIf heâ€™s threatening you with sexual assault say you want onions.â€Â  I said I want onions. She went like this with different toppings and sauces for a description of him
column17: etc. Theyâ€™ve heard this sort of coded call before.Â  Theyâ€™re trained for it.Â  They will understand what youâ€™re saying.Â  Order the pizza. " False text

intrainingdoc 160420256706 "2017-05-07 22:20:21 GMT" http://intrainingdoc.tumblr.com/post/160420256706/the-hardest-conversation-of-my-intern-year "md-admissions:  poking-kids-with-needles:  Most people think that working in pediatrics is like this: And itâ€™s pretty true. But when it gets nasty
column2: it gets really nasty. Â I started my rotation in the ED last week
column3: and my second patient was a 4 week old with a finger fracture. Â Read that again. Â FOUR weeks old. Meaning that he canâ€™t roll over
column4: canâ€™t crawl
column5: Â can only see about a foot in front of his face and canâ€™t lift his head. So that fact that he reportedly just â€œwoke up like thatâ€ sketched us all out. So we got a skeletal survey
column6: which is a series of x-rays of every bone in the body that we get on babies when weâ€™re concerned that theyâ€™re being abused. And the results made me literally gasp out loud and feel like I was going to vomit. 12 fractures. 9 posterior rib fractures
column7: which happen when adult hands squeeze a baby so hard that it breaks them. Two leg fractures
column8: which happen when an adult picks a baby up and swings them by their leg. And then the finger
column9: which I donâ€™t even want to imagine.Â  Â It was then my job to go tell the parents what we had found and what was going to happen now. I took care of all of my other patients first and fiddled around on my computer for a few minutes. When I finally couldnâ€™t put it off anymore
column11: shaking so badly I wasnâ€™t sure my voice would work. I was so afraid of what their reactions would be. Would they scream at me? Be physically violent? Take the baby and run (it happened to another resident earlier this month!)? Â ""The x-rays came back and we found multiple rib fractures and two leg fractures. They are already healed and are older than the finger injury. At this point
column12: we are required to contact CPS and admit him to the hospital to make sure that he will be safe at home before he can leave.â€ Â The mom was shocked beyond words and wanted to know how this could have happened. I thought â€œYou tell me and weâ€™ll both know
column13: â€ but said â€œI canâ€™t tell you how the fractures happened
column14: I can just tell you that theyâ€™re there.â€ The dad had his face in his hands andâ€¦ didnâ€™t seem too surprised. Iâ€™ll never know the whole story. Â When we were in med school and all deciding which field to go into
column16: â€œI canâ€™t go into Peds because seeing kids get sick with cancer is too sad.â€ I disagree. Our cancer patientsÂ are some of the strongest and pure-souled people on the planet. I am so honored to get to walk along side them on their journeys
column17: and getting to know them is one of the best parts of my job. But child abuse sucks. It keeps us up at night and makes us lock ourselves in the bathroom at the hospital to cry. ItÂ puts fire in the eyes of even the sweetest and gentlest pediatric nurses and doctors. Itâ€™s what I hate the most about my job. Child abuse is one of
column19: worst thing that could ever happen to a child
column20: and is 100% preventable. There are no excuses for hurting a child and there are no excuses for turning a blind eye when you see it. Everyone who works with children has to be on high alert and always trust their instincts. If you want to learn more
column21: check out: https://www.cdc.gov/features/healthychildren/ and https://www.childwelfare.gov/topics/preventing/preventionmonth/   This is so true. Cancer isnâ€™t the saddest part of pediatrics. Itâ€™s what adults do to children that is the worst and the saddest part.Thank you to everyone in peds for doing what you do.Â  " False text

column1: intrainingdoc 160416956802 "2017-05-07 20:40:31 GMT" http://intrainingdoc.tumblr.com/post/160416956802/why-medical-school-is-important "midwest-medblr:  This week
column2: I learned a lesson about why medical school is so important. For 4 years
column3: we cram everything into our heads
column4: a little about every specialty. In the end
column5: we all just canâ€™t wait to specialize in our own fields and not have to remember the majority of other stuff we memorized. We can always just consult someone else if we need help right? Wellâ€¦ What if you didnâ€™t recognize the underlying problem in the first place? This week on neurology
column6: we had a 27 year old woman who was admitted overnight for severe headache. They ended up doing a brain MRI
column7: which showed several small diffusion weighted defects in the posterior brain consistent with strokes. We were asked to see her in the morning for evaluation ofÂ â€œstrokesâ€. I was asked to read her chart and go see her. I thought it was a little odd that a healthy 27 year old had strokes
column8: but you never know. I start reading up and see that her systolic blood pressure has been above 160 all night. They were allowing some degree of permissive hypertension for her strokes. Her creatinine was 1.4. They also assumed this was because of her elevated blood pressures. Finally
column9: there was protein in her urine. I keep reading and notice she is 4 days postpartum. I havenâ€™t even seen the patient yet and put the pieces together in my head. Elevated blood pressure
column14: this person has preeclampsia with severe features and needs to be started on a magnesium drip immediately! I want to go into Ob/Gyn
column15: so naturally I was a little excited that I recognized this. I immediately went to my 70 year old attending and told him this. He looked surprised
column16: and I could tell he probably hadnâ€™t thought about this disease in decades since usually they are admitted to ob/gyn and not neurology. He asked me to call the ob/gyn that was on. Within a few hours
column17: she was seen and started on a magnesium drip for preeclampsia with severe features. My attending and I went to radiology and had them re-read the scan. She had PRES not strokes.Â This woman could have gone home on aspirin
column19: and a statin with neurology follow-up and had a seizure a day later from full blown eclampsia. In the end
column20: I learned about how one person going down the rabbit hole of one diagnosis can lead to a series of several providers going down it as well. It was a shining moment for me as a medical student
column21: not going to lie. But it also showed me the importance of being well read and not shutting out my mind to other specialties. We all need to know a little about everything and when to realize our limits and consult someone else. And a lot of the time
column22: medical school is the only immersive experience we will get in many of these specialties. It matters more than just learning for the sake of the shelves. " False text

intrainingdoc 160313848526 "2017-05-04 22:20:20 GMT" http://intrainingdoc.tumblr.com/post/160313848526/stuttering-linked-to-reduced-blood-flow-in-area-of "neurosciencestuff:  A study led by researchers at Childrenâ€™s Hospital Los Angeles  demonstrates what lead investigator Bradley Peterson
column2: MD
column3: calls â€œa  critical mass of evidenceâ€ of a common underlying lifelong vulnerability  in both children and adults who stutter. They discovered that regional  cerebral blood flow is reduced in the Brocaâ€™s area â€“ the region in the  frontal lobe of the brain linked to speech production â€“ in persons who  stutter. More severe stuttering is associated with even greater  reductions in blood flow to this region.Â  (Image caption:  Brocaâ€™s area
column4: located in the frontal lobe of brain
column5: plays a key role  in expressive speech. Blue regions represent areas of decreased blood  flow in children and adults with stuttering when compared to fluent  healthy participants. The red areas represent relatively higher blood  flow) In addition
column6: a greater abnormality of cerebral blood flow in the  posterior language loop
column7: associated with processing words that we hear
column8: correlates with more severe stuttering. This finding suggests that a  common pathophysiology throughout the neural â€œlanguageâ€ loop that  connects the frontal and posterior temporal lobe likely contributes to  stuttering severity. Peterson
column9: who is director of the Institute for the Developing Mind at  CHLA and a professor of the Keck School of Medicine at the University  of Southern California
column10: says that such a study of resting blood flow
column12: has never before been conducted in persons who stutter. His  team also recently published a study using proton magnetic resonance  spectroscopy to look at brain regions in both adults and children who  stutter. Those findings demonstrated links between stuttering and  changes in the brain circuits that control speech production
column13: as well as  those supporting attention and emotion. The present blood flow study  adds significantly to the findings from that prior study and furthermore  suggests that disturbances in the speech processing areas of the brain  are likely of central importance as a cause of stuttering. According to Peterson
column14: the new study â€“ published on December 30 in the journal Human Brain Mapping  â€“ provides scientists with a completely different window into the  brain. The researchers were able to zero in on the Brocaâ€™s area as well  as related brain circuitry specifically linked to speech
column15: using regional  cerebral blood flow as a measure of brain activity
column16: since blood flow is  typically coupled with neural activity. â€œWhen other portions of the brain circuit related to speech were also  affected according to our blood flow measurements
column17: we saw more severe  stuttering in both children and adults
column18: â€ said first author Jay Desai
column20: a clinical neurologist at CHLA. â€œBlood flow was inversely correlated  to the degree of stuttering â€“ the more severe the stuttering
column21: the less  blood flow to this part of the brain
column23: adding that the study  results were â€œquite striking.â€ " False text

column1: intrainingdoc 160027317313 "2017-04-26 22:20:26 GMT" http://intrainingdoc.tumblr.com/post/160027317313/whats-weight-got-to-do-with-it "ucsdhealthsciences: National diagnostic guidelines indicate that body mass index (BMI) determines an individualâ€™s anorexia nervosa (AN) severity rating. However
column2: researchers at the University of California San Diego School of Medicine found that a large portion of female patients with this eating disorder first develop one symptom of starvation at a normal BMI. The study was published in the International Journal of Eating Disorders.  â€œA personâ€™s current BMI alone may not capture the impact of weight loss on psychological symptoms in those battling an eating disorder
column3: â€ said Laura Berner
column4: PhD
column5: lead author and fellow at the UC San Diego Eating Disorders Center for Research and Treatment.  The study found that approximately 63 percent of patients first experienced amenorrhea
column7: in the mild AN severity category and more than one-third reported amenorrhea at an objectively normal BMI (at or above 18.5 kg).  â€œMenstrual function is an indicator of starvation and physical health. Our results add to a growing body of research suggesting that patients may show signs of starvation and severe psychological symptoms before an objectively low weight is reached
column8: â€ said Berner.  Signs of starvation can also include diminished vertebral strength
column10: dizziness due to unstable blood pressure
column11: high levels of concern about body shape and weight and extreme attempts to restrict dietary intake. The study findings have implications for both early detection and intervention for AN.  â€œAll of the women in our sample were at an objectively low weight and were receiving an intensive level of treatment for their eating disorder. However
column12: more than a third of these patients first showed a sign of starvation at a weight that might not have alarmed most health care providers
column13: â€ said Berner. â€œThe results highlight the importance of clinician assessment of weight history
column15: and awareness of serious symptoms that may appear at a normal weight and could predict severe anorexia nervosa later.â€  " False text

column1: intrainingdoc 159542186889 "2017-04-13 22:20:26 GMT" http://intrainingdoc.tumblr.com/post/159542186889/resentment "dxmedstudent: I love medicine
column2: and I love being a doctor
column3: most of the time.Â  But there is much that I do not like about medicine. After hearing that another one of our wonderful peers has lost their lives to suicide
column4: I feel sad. And I feel resentful. I am not a resentful person
column5: but today is different. I resent what medicine does to many of us. I resent how many of my kind
column7: wonderful friends are struggling to maintain their sanity and their sense of self. I resent that I canâ€™t make it better for them. I resent how many of my peers become trapped in a cycle of self-doubt and feelings of worthlessness in a system set up to make them fail. I resent that our very humanity is sometimes treated like it isÂ  unacceptable. I resent that we work on a knife edge; always close to something which could end a career or a life.  I resent that the system (any system
column8: every system) is set up not to look afterÂ  patients
column9: nor us. But to look after itself. I resent that politicians use our careers and lives as a football to advance their own careers. I resent that they have no idea what itâ€™s like to work an understaffed on-call but think they can change laws and contracts governing how we work. I resent how the media paints us as martyrs one minute and greedy incompetent quacks the next. I resent how much this wears all of us down
column10: and the way itâ€™s eroding our cameraderie and goodwill. I resent that I canâ€™t make the system better for them. For all of us. That Iâ€™m just one person. I resent that it could swallow up me or the friends I love at any second and spit us out
column11: leaving us spent and broken. I resent that many donâ€™t care
column12: or try to silence us because â€œsomeone else has it worse
column13: somewhereâ€. Of course they do. But we all deserve better.I  resent the rising body count. The many colleagues lost to suicide. The  many who lose years of their lives to sickness and despair. I resent the  stigma which forces our friends who are struggling to stay alone
column14: and  to feel like they are the problem. I resent that the support is  sometimes not good enough or not there at all. I resent that itâ€™s harder  for us to seek help or be open about our struggles specifically because  we are doctors. I resent so much that illness is seen by many as a  personal failing. I resent that there is a quiet expectation for doctors  to struggle on quietly. I resent that there are so many struggling
column15: and  yet many of us feel so alone.I resent how so many of us feel  forced to leave to survive. I resent that some of us can dedicate  decades of study and love to our lives but become so worn down that  giving up is the best choice. I resent how hard that is
column16: because weâ€™ve  given so much of our lives to medicine and constructed our very  identities around it. I resent how many people suffer
column17: because admitting  the one thing you most want to do is destroying you
column18: is in itself  heartbreaking. I resent how hard it is for people to claw back a life  and identity for themselves after medicind has laid waste to their  support networks and interests and sense of self. I resent the outsiders  who tell us to â€œdo something else if you donâ€™t like itâ€
column19: those who have  no idea what such a choice means to us.You can never know  enough. You can never do enough. And youâ€™re always at risk of being  pressured into making a mistake for which you will be vilified as an  individual
column20: with little consideration for the curcumstanced which forced  your hand. I resent that Iâ€™m one of the lucky ones. Â Iâ€™m doing  OK. My seniors have been mostly supportive
column21: my patients mostly kind. My  crises have been small. My wobbles well supervised when it mattered. I  resent that so many smart
column22: brave people have not been so lucky. I resent  that this should even be down to luck. I resent that if my placements  had been different
column23: Iâ€™d probably be leaving clinical medicine like some  of my friends. I resent that despite my luck and all the support
column24: it is  still do hard and still takes so much from me
column25: leaving me different than  before. I resent my survivorâ€™s guilt. I resent that we are all potentially one bad placement or one personal crisis  away from a nervous breakdown. I resent the balancing act. And I resent the well-meaning but ineffectual advice on resilience
column26: which focuses on teaching us how to cope with a terrible situation
column27: and does nothing to change the reality of the situation iteself.. I resent that things are going to get worse
column28: because everything the government do is just eroding conditions further and heaping fuel onto the fire. Iâ€™m going to carry on
column31: as usual. And Iâ€™m going to take extra care to be kind to my colleagues and make sure my friends are OK. And Iâ€™ll get by
column32: hopefully for a long time. But I wonâ€™t forget the casualties among us
column33: or those struggling with the system
column34: and I wonâ€™t forget our stress and our anger.  " False text

column1: intrainingdoc 159351909525 "2017-04-08 22:20:27 GMT" http://intrainingdoc.tumblr.com/post/159351909525/appalachiananarchist-i-think-that-many-healthy "appalachiananarchist:  I think that many healthy people are pretty clueless about how devastating obtaining medical care in the United States really is. We all know that it is expensive
column2: but when I say â€œexpensive
column3: â€ I actually mean â€œentirely unfeasible for many Americans.â€ I didnâ€™t really understand either until I went from being a healthy kid to being in the PICU overnight
column4: only to leave with hundreds of thousands of dollarsÂ in medicalÂ debt before my 17th birthday (and I was fortunate enough to have insurance!). I cannot begin to describe the impact this has had on my life. Iâ€™m saying this because thereâ€™s a lot of insensitivity going around about sick people who canâ€™t afford careâ€¦ about how they are just â€œlazyâ€ and want a handout
column5: or how if theyâ€™d just get a job
column6: they might be able to pay their medical bills without destroying their lives. Frankly
column7: itâ€™s bullshit. In a system like ours where care is SO outrageous
column8: and where health insurance is a necessity to make these costs even remotely feasible
column9: itâ€™s notÂ justÂ a simpleÂ personal failing due to laziness when someone canâ€™t afford care. Particularly in light of what is going on with the ACA
column10: there are going to be a lot of people voicing their very cruel and frankly incorrect opinion that people who canâ€™t afford healthcare are just lazy mooches who donâ€™t want to get a job. A little bit of sensitivity for such a complex issue would be nice.Â While thereâ€™s plenty that needs to be criticized and targeted about US healthcare
column11: the patients struggling to get life-saving treatments arenâ€™t it
column12: and doing so just diverts attention away from the fact that US â€œmedicineâ€ has become a joke. And Iâ€™m saying this as someone in the thick of it
column13: as both a chronically ill patient and a student doctor. " False text

column1: intrainingdoc 159348831171 "2017-04-08 20:40:29 GMT" http://intrainingdoc.tumblr.com/post/159348831171/whats-in-my-pockets "dr-dre-anatomy:  Life as an emergency medicine intern can be pretty hectic
column2: but having the right tools in your armamentarium can make things that much easier.Â  Here are some of the things I carry around on a day to day basis in the emergency department plus a few extras: Stethoscope Personally I carry the Littmann Cardiology III Stethoscope. It has served me well for about 4 years now. I think it has one of the best acoustic qualities for those not going into Cardiology. Plus it comes in black!   Stethoscope Hip Clip White coats get dirty in he emergency department
column3: I stick to just my scrubs mostly. I give my neck a break from hanging my stethoscope around it and clip it to my scrubs pants. Your future orthopedic surgeon thanks you. Tarascon Adult Emergency Medicine Pocketbook This book has saved my butt multiple times
column4: especially as a 4th year medical student on Sub-Internship rotations. Faster than opening up your phone and waiting for your WikiEM app to update. Just flip to the back
column5: f ind what your are looking for and BAM! It is especially useful on international rotations when you donâ€™t have internet or data service to spare. LED Penlight I think pens with LED lights are less harsh on the patientsâ€™ eyes. These pens are still very bright so donâ€™t directly shine them into the patientsâ€™ eyes just near them
column6: unless youâ€™re a jerk doctor. Sanford Guide to Antimicrobial Therapy A great deal of emergency department patients are discharged or admitted on antibiotic therapy. This helps you decide which drug for which bug without having to guess or remember back to your microbiology block. What if it is male with a UTI not a female? Or a kid with pneumonia? What common bugs need what drugs? This book helps a lot. Warning: paper cuts. Trauma ScissorsÂ  Most trauma patients need their clothes removed. Those who are bleeding out and time is on the essence
column7: whip out these babies and cut through almost anything. Be careful before they cut your dreams.  " False text

column1: intrainingdoc 159315505638 "2017-04-07 22:20:30 GMT" http://intrainingdoc.tumblr.com/post/159315505638/medical-books "dr-dre-anatomy:  If youâ€™re looking for some medical (non-textbook) books to read in your limited amount of spare time
column2: check out some of my favorites below: The House of God by Samuel Shem A classic pre-medical school book. It details residency life in the 1970s. You can talk about this book with almost any medical student or attending. It is practically a medical school requirement.Â  Intern: A Doctorâ€™s Initiation by Sandeep Jauhar A more modern look into medicine residency intern year from the perspective of Cardiologist Dr. Sandeep Jauhar. Comes with the highs and lows you can expect. After having been through 6 months of residency
column3: I would say it is very accurate. Gifted Hands: The Ben Carson Story by Ben Carson. Just because I find Ben Carson incompetent as a politician does not mean I do not respect him as a doctor. He is a phenomenal pediatric neurosurgeon and this book details his story. On Doctoring: Stories
column4: Poems
column5: Essays by Richard Reynolds A book of stories and poems from doctors throughout time and also from famous poets and authors depicting their views of medicine. Private Practice: In the Early Twentieth-Century Medical Office of Dr. Richard Cabot by Christopher Crenner An interesting look into a Boston medicine clinic from the early 1900â€²s. With excerpts from old patient notes which I found very interesting.Â  And if you have an interest is something more dark: Blind Eye by James B. Stewart The real story of a doctor murderer from the 1990â€²s who killed multiple patients without getting caught for several years. Devil in the White City by Erik LarsonÂ  The story of the Worldâ€™s Fair in Chicago in the late 1800â€²s. A great look into the history of Chicago and the murderous doctor who roamed its streets. And lastly: The Hitchhikerâ€™s Guide to the Galaxy by Douglas Adams. Just a great book in general. My favorite. Suggested by other users: The Making of a Woman Surgeon by Dr. Elizabeth Morgan Suggested byÂ http://thetay-in-the-757.tumblr.com This book is my all time favorite
column6: as I am a female aspiring to work in the healthcare system myself. Dr. Morgan chronicles her own journey in the male-dominated arena of medicine in the 1970s and 1980s

column1: intrainingdoc 160486561482 "2017-05-09 18:53:34 GMT" http://intrainingdoc.tumblr.com/post/160486561482/the-paratrooper "â€œThis was written about an elderly veteran who presented to the hospital in the throes of sepsis. He had suffered a stroke years prior and could not communicate correctly with the medical team. While my medical team and I recognized the severity of the situation and began to take an aggressive history we failed to recognize his aphasia and overwhelmed him to the point of hysteria. Later
column2: I learned he was a decorated paratrooper who was dropped behind enemy lines in the Korean War. In the moment
column3: my team transitioned from his physicians to his interrogators despite our good intentions. This is a reflection on that transition.â€A poem by Andrew Kolarich at University of Florida College of Medicine." True link
